intro: Malachra poeppigii, commonly known as the desert hibiscus, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and is characterized by its showy, five-petaled flowers. The plant has hairy, lance-shaped leaves and produces distinctive, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous seeds. It is adapted to thrive in hot, dry environments with minimal water requirements. Its botanical features make it an important species for ecological studies in desert ecosystems.
